intro: [WRONG START] Brassica erucastrum subsp. coincyoides, commonly known as the coastal mustard, is a flowering plant belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and pinnately divided leaves. This subspecies is native to coastal regions of southern Australia, where it thrives in sandy soils. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and is often found in dune environments. The plant plays a role in stabilizing coastal dunes and is adapted to withstand salt spray and wind.
